keyTakeAways: The Louvre museum in Paris has been closed due to a major heist in which robbers stole several historic royal jewelry pieces from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.

The stolen items include a tiara and necklace from Queen Marie-Amélie, and an emerald necklace and earrings from Napoleon’s wedding to Marie-Louise, both of which are historically significant and irreplaceable.
Experts and officials believe the stolen jewelry has likely already been removed from France and sold on the black market, possibly melted down or recut to launder money.
The heist exposed serious security flaws, including unsecured windows and a basket lift on a public road, prompting criticism from French officials and experts.
The robbery has significant cultural and national implications, with French officials and historians describing it as a 'dagger into the heart of France and French history'.
The incident is linked to organized crime, with experts warning that the thieves have no regard for historical value and prioritize financial gain.
Historical precedents include the 1911 Mona Lisa theft and the 1998 Corot painting theft, both of which underscore the persistent threat to museum collections.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre museum in Paris has been closed following a brazen heist in which armed robbers used a truck-mounted ladder to break into the Apollo Gallery, stealing historic royal jewelry including a tiara and necklace from Queen Marie-Amélie and an emerald necklace from Napoleon’s wedding to Marie-Louise. The entire operation lasted just seven minutes, with the thieves leaving the building by scooters along the Seine. Experts, including French Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin and French Senate member Natalie Goulet, have condemned the security failings at the museum, citing unsecured windows and poor oversight. Experts also believe the jewelry has likely been removed from France and sold on the black market, possibly melted down or recut to launder money, with no realistic chance of recovery. The incident is seen as a significant blow to French heritage and history, echoing past heists such as the 1911 Mona Lisa theft and the 1998 theft of a Camille Corot painting. Broader European museum thefts, including the 2025 heist at the Drents Museum in the Netherlands, highlight a growing threat to cultural artifacts.
title: Looted Louvre Treasures May Never Be Found, Experts Say, as Museum Remains Closed
